text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section and these are my turkey giblets
and I'm going to show you how to make
lumpless gravy but before we get to
actually making the gravy I want to tell
you something that you probably don't
know about making gravy you can make it
entirely ahead I mean think about it
there you are on Thanksgiving you've got
the turkey 2-car if you've got your
entire family in the other room
clamoring for their dinner the last
thing you want to be doing is whisking a
roux and pouring in hot stock to make a
gravy base so what I've got right here
this is the turkey neck and this is the
bag of giblets that's usually stuffed
inside the turkey there are a lot of
things in here that have tons of flavor
and what you want to do is make them
into stock first thing we're gonna do is
open the bag and see what exactly is in
there
aha these are the turkey deserts right
here these gizzards have so much flavor
you definitely want the gizzard and the
neck to go into the stocks that's the
first step to a delicious gravy is
having a really intense full flavored
stock you know how to do that you just
heat up your stock and then you add the
giblets to the simmering stock and you
let it infuse and flavor the broth for
about an hour on low heat and now we're
gonna make the gravy there are two
critical stages to ensuring lump-free
gravy the first one is after you melt
your butter you want to add your flour
in kind of gradually you sprinkle your
flour in and at the same time you are
whisking the heck out of it
you really gotta whisk the whole time
that you're adding the flour to make
sure that there are no lumps that are
forming second step is when you add your
stock you do that in two stages you add
just a little bit of stock to the roux
once it's got that beautiful gold color
just enough stock to kind of loosen it
and then you also you're beating out any
lumps and then you add the rest of the
stock and then you continue to beat
until you're sure that all the lumps are
done it only takes about a minute and
now I'm just gonna stir every few
minutes until it reduces to the
thickness that I want I like my gravy
along the thin side I like it to be less
like heavy cream and more like rich
half-and-half
now I'm gonna taste it to make sure
there's enough salt and pepper and I can
correct the seasonings at this point
a little more salt at this point the
gravy is finished this is delicious
gravy you can make it a couple of days
ahead put it in your fridge and then
just bring it back to a simmer on the
stove right before you serve your turkey
or if you want to take the gravy to the
next level I'm gonna show you a trick
with the pan drippings so all I'm doing
is I'm bringing these Turkey drippings
to a simmer and I am scraping up all
those glorious brown bits that are stuck
to the bottom of the pan and that's
where your flavor is okay now I'm just
gonna whisk those yummy juices right
into the gravy this one is a very light
flavored gravy it really tastes like
Turkey it's delicious but if you want a
deep really rich flavor gravy when
you're adding the flour and you're
cooking the roux just let it cook to a
dark brown and then you're gonna get a
lot more flavor okay I'm all set
I've got the turkey I just roasted I got
the super-easy gravy I just made now all
